docs.snippet: A task force working for the World Anti-Doping Agency says the officials blackmailed athletes who doped and failed to discipline them in a timely fashion....
docs.lead_paragraph: A task force working for the World Anti-Doping Agency says the officials blackmailed athletes who doped and failed to discipline them in a timely fashion.
docs.abstract: World Anti-Doping Agency report accuses international sports officials of blackmailing some track and field athletes who failed drug tests and choosing not to discipline runners who were suspected of doping; report also provides specific details of some athletes who were extorted; charges are seen as new low for officials.

headline.main: Officials Accused of Extortion to Clear Athletes Who Doped
headline.print_headline: In Annals of Bribes and Scams, One Sport Pushes Bar Lower

docs.snippet: Those countries, which have significant atomic stockpiles or nuclear power plants, do little to protect them from such intrusions, the Nuclear Threat Initiative says....
docs.lead_paragraph: Those countries, which have significant atomic stockpiles or nuclear power plants, do little to protect them from such intrusions, the Nuclear Threat Initiative says.
docs.abstract: Nuclear Threat Initiative study says twenty countries lack rules requiring protection of their nuclear facilities against cyberattacks; emerging consensus points to cyberattack as simplest way to breach installations' security systems; report also shows Pres Obama's campaign to secure nuclear material worldwide has slowed, which some blame on frayed ties with Russia.

headline.main: Nuclear Facilities in 20 Countries May Be Easy Targets for Cyberattacks
headline.print_headline: Nuclear Facilities in 20 Countries May Be Easy Targets for Cyberattacks

docs.snippet: It can be difficult to find purity at the top of international sports. Despite corruption in track and field, Coe, the I.A.A.F. president, still may be the best option....
docs.lead_paragraph: It can be difficult to find purity at the top of international sports. Despite corruption in track and field, Coe, the I.A.A.F. president, still may be the best option.
docs.abstract: Juliet Macur Sports of The Times column supports suggestion from Richard W Pound, former chief of World Anti-Doping Agency, that International Assn of Athletics Federations president Sebastian Coe is right man to clean up doping in world of track and field; suggests, however, that Coe first allow independent reform committee to take over IAAF and rebuild its governance structure before he returns to run federation like public company.

headline.main: A Second Chance for Sebastian Coe to Clean Up His Sport
headline.print_headline: A Second Chance to Take the Lead
